BIOS106
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to build on initial experience in experimental and computational techniques delivered in the first semester to develop essential practical skills currently used across the Biosciences. The module is designed so that students will acquire fundamental experimental and computational biology techniques that are vital for all aspects of Biosciences, before applying them to field specific problems in one of three topical strands (Molecular Research, Anatomical & Physiological Research, Whole Organism Field Research).

Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advancements in the biosciences, and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative of the student cohort.

This practical will be assessed via three methods: a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of bioinformatic and computational skills; an individual practical skills assessment in the form of observation or online assessment to assess knowledge, understanding and application of knowledge; a written scientific report to assess data analyses and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
1. To provide students with experience in a number of practical techniques, analytical methods and associated computational skills that are applicable to many fields across the Biosciences disciplines.

2. To develop and further understanding of theoretical knowledge in the context of practical skills and exercises.

3. To apply practical & field skills to specific Biosciences disciplines related to topical areas.

4. To train students how to observe and record experiments, and how to present and analyse data

5. To expose students to bioinformatic tools and online databases used in the biosciences and provide students with a practical appreciation of the nature and significance of computational approaches to tackling biological problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Biology is a practical science, whether you want to study disease in microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans), understand the function of a gene, or how the behaviour of organisms can shape an ecosystem. In the first half of this module, all students will learn fundamental practical techniques that every biologist should be familiar with. Alongside the experimental skills, students will learn practical computational and bioinformatic methods that can be used to support and advance scientific understanding of the lab techniques. In the second half, students will split into three topical strands: Molecular Research, Anatomical & Physiological Research or Whole Organism Field Research. Students in each strand will learn a set of skills and techniques that are particularly useful for degree course, with a focus on their specific discipline. All students will learn how to safely and effectively carry out practical biology, skills that will be vital throughout the rest of your degree.

Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advancements in the biosciences, and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative of the student cohort.

This practical will be assessed via three methods: a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of bioinformatic and computational skills; an individual practical skills assessment in the form of observation or online assessment to assess knowledge, understanding and application of knowledge; a written scientific report to assess data analyses and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Outline Syllabus
In the first half of the module, all students will learn fundamental practical techniques that every biologist should be familiar with. In the first part of the module each practical session will be supported by a theoretical bioinformatics session and computational workshop as follows:

Practicals will include:
Topic 1: Molecular tools & DNA. Covering topics such as the extraction of DNA, quantification and quality control methods, including health and safety and methods of good lab practice.

Topic 2: Polymerase Chain Reaction & DNA Mutations. Covering topics such as the amplification of DNA to identify gene mutations related to disease systems.

Topic 3: Use of model systems in Biosciences. Covering topics such as fly cross or plant cross models to showcase functional expression and phenotypic changes

Topic 4: Gene editing. Covering topics such as novel gene editing technologies (e.g. Crispr-CAS) and Genetic Modification (e.g. GMOs and organisms).

Bioinformatics will include:
- Nucleic acid and amino acid sequence alignment methods and tools.
- Primer design.
- Model organism databases.
- Methods for predicting structure, function and interactions of proteins.
- Computational methods to understand phylogeny and evolution.

In the second half of the module students will split into three topical strands: Molecular Biology, Anatomy & Physiology or Whole Organism/Field Biology.

Strand 1: Molecular Biology
Topic A: Plasmid Cloning: May include techniques such as: Restriction digestion of Plasmids; transformation
Topic B: Separation methods for biomolecules. May include techniques such as: gel filtration; ion exchange chromatography
Topic C: Protein purification. May include techniques such as column chromatography
Topic D: SDS-PAGE analyses, protein concentration quantification
Topic E: Protein denaturation and stability analyses

Strand 2: Anatomy & Physiology
Topic A: Plasmid Cloning: May include techniques such as: Restriction digestion of Plasmids; transformation
Topic B: Separation methods for biomolecules. May include techniques such as: gel filtration; ion exchange chromatography
Topic C: Musculoskeletal anatomy and physiological methods
Topic D: Cardiovascular anatomy and physiological methods
Topic E: Respiratory anatomy and physiological methods

Strand 3: Whole Organism/Field Biology
Topic A: Key features of major animals groups
Topic B: Studying populations and their behaviour in the field: assessing behaviour responses and estimating population size
Topic C: Studying species interactions in the field: determining traits of species and how these differences determine interspecies interactions.
Topic D: Studying ecosystem-organism interactions in the field: measuring key ecosystem traits and how they affect and are affected by the species in the ecosystem.
Topic E. Fieldwork safety and experimental design
Teaching and Learning Methods
In a typical week students will attend one or two 1hr lecture/theoretical sessions (one based on the practical work one introducing bioinformatics concepts, a 3 hr practical and a 2hr computational workshop or data analysis session. Students on the whole organism strand weeks 7-12 will also attend fieldwork.

Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also incorporate application of computational biology approaches & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Practical Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills in laboratory (or Human Anatomy Resource Centre)

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity through self-directed learning.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Field Work: Time spent in the field. A series of experiments will be carried out each day, ranging from identification experiments, behavioural observations, systematically sampling natural populations, observing how traits allow species to compete or coexist, and investigating ecosystem interactions.

Teaching Method 5

Self-directed video-based learning to introduce applied computational biology skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, bioinformatics tools and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 6

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Computer Practical's are delivered online or synchronously by lecturers and studentâs questions are addressed by lecturers and demonstrators.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the life sciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The lab skills assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills, continual learning and development and appreciation of the theoretical knowledge. Online computational assessment will allow students to implement theoretical knowledge of bioinformatic and computational skills that supplement experimental practices, in order to tackle scientific problems related to wider fields of Biosciences. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific report (s) is highly authentic for practical application of research and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a âsafe spaceâ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and bioinformatics practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.


The mode of assessments include:

1. Online Assessment MCQ/MAQ/EMI Assessment (weighting 30% at the end of teaching block. The questions will require interpretation of lab based experimental techniques and bioinformatics analysis outputs, alongside application of these skills. The students will need to interpret the outputs and understand their significance. (Research connected teaching, Digital Fluency - Liverpool Curriculum). Open book and resit allowed.

2. Practical skills assessment (weighting 20%) based on skills acquired in field specific strand. Can be undertaken via online assessment or physical demonstration (in the case of Whole organism field strand) to assess competency. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

3. Written Scientific Report (s) (weighting 50%) based on the skills to evaluate and interpret and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed


Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

2. Practical skills assessment (weighting 20%) based on skills acquired in field specific strand. Can be undertaken via online assessment or physical demonstration (in the case of Whole organism field strand) to assess competency. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

3. Written Scientific Report (s) (weighting 50%) based on the skills to evaluate and interpret and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed


Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS106
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to build on initial experience in experimental and computational techniques delivered in the first semester to develop essential practical skills currently used across the Biosciences. The module is designed so that students will acquire fundamental experimental and computational biology techniques that are vital for all aspects of Biosciences, before applying them to field specific problems in one of three topical strands (Molecular Research, Anatomical & Physiological Research, Whole Organism Field Research).

Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advancements in the biosciences, and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative of the student cohort.

This practical will be assessed via three methods: a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of bioinformatic and computational skills; an individual practical skills assessment in the form of observation or online assessment to assess knowledge, understanding and application of knowledge; a written scientific report to assess data analyses and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
1. To provide students with experience in a number of practical techniques, analytical methods and associated computational skills that are applicable to many fields across the Biosciences disciplines.

2. To develop and further understanding of theoretical knowledge in the context of practical skills and exercises.

3. To apply practical & field skills to specific Biosciences disciplines related to topical areas.

4. To train students how to observe and record experiments, and how to present and analyse data

5. To expose students to bioinformatic tools and online databases used in the biosciences and provide students with a practical appreciation of the nature and significance of computational approaches to tackling biological problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Biology is a practical science, whether you want to study disease in microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans), understand the function of a gene, or how the behaviour of organisms can shape an ecosystem. In the first half of this module, all students will learn fundamental practical techniques that every biologist should be familiar with. Alongside the experimental skills, students will learn practical computational and bioinformatic methods that can be used to support and advance scientific understanding of the lab techniques. In the second half, students will split into three topical strands: Molecular Research, Anatomical & Physiological Research or Whole Organism Field Research. Students in each strand will learn a set of skills and techniques that are particularly useful for degree course, with a focus on their specific discipline. All students will learn how to safely and effectively carry out practical biology, skills that will be vital throughout the rest of your degree.

Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advancements in the biosciences, and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative of the student cohort.

This practical will be assessed via three methods: a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of bioinformatic and computational skills; an individual practical skills assessment in the form of observation or online assessment to assess knowledge, understanding and application of knowledge; a written scientific report to assess data analyses and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Outline Syllabus
In the first half of the module, all students will learn fundamental practical techniques that every biologist should be familiar with. In the first part of the module each practical session will be supported by a theoretical bioinformatics session and computational workshop as follows:

Practicals will include:
Topic 1: Molecular tools & DNA. Covering topics such as the extraction of DNA, quantification and quality control methods, including health and safety and methods of good lab practice.

Topic 2: Polymerase Chain Reaction & DNA Mutations. Covering topics such as the amplification of DNA to identify gene mutations related to disease systems.

Topic 3: Use of model systems in Biosciences. Covering topics such as fly cross or plant cross models to showcase functional expression and phenotypic changes

Topic 4: Gene editing. Covering topics such as novel gene editing technologies (e.g. Crispr-CAS) and Genetic Modification (e.g. GMOs and organisms).

Bioinformatics will include:
- Nucleic acid and amino acid sequence alignment methods and tools.
- Primer design.
- Model organism databases.
- Methods for predicting structure, function and interactions of proteins.
- Computational methods to understand phylogeny and evolution.

In the second half of the module students will split into three topical strands: Molecular Biology, Anatomy & Physiology or Whole Organism/Field Biology.

Strand 1: Molecular Biology
Topic A: Plasmid Cloning: May include techniques such as: Restriction digestion of Plasmids; transformation
Topic B: Separation methods for biomolecules. May include techniques such as: gel filtration; ion exchange chromatography
Topic C: Protein purification. May include techniques such as column chromatography
Topic D: SDS-PAGE analyses, protein concentration quantification
Topic E: Protein denaturation and stability analyses

Strand 2: Anatomy & Physiology
Topic A: Plasmid Cloning: May include techniques such as: Restriction digestion of Plasmids; transformation
Topic B: Separation methods for biomolecules. May include techniques such as: gel filtration; ion exchange chromatography
Topic C: Musculoskeletal anatomy and physiological methods
Topic D: Cardiovascular anatomy and physiological methods
Topic E: Respiratory anatomy and physiological methods

Strand 3: Whole Organism/Field Biology
Topic A: Key features of major animals groups
Topic B: Studying populations and their behaviour in the field: assessing behaviour responses and estimating population size
Topic C: Studying species interactions in the field: determining traits of species and how these differences determine interspecies interactions.
Topic D: Studying ecosystem-organism interactions in the field: measuring key ecosystem traits and how they affect and are affected by the species in the ecosystem.
Topic E. Fieldwork safety and experimental design
Teaching and Learning Methods
In a typical week students will attend one or two 1hr lecture/theoretical sessions (one based on the practical work one introducing bioinformatics concepts, a 3 hr practical and a 2hr computational workshop or data analysis session. Students on the whole organism strand weeks 7-12 will also attend fieldwork.

Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also incorporate application of computational biology approaches & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Practical Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills in laboratory (or Human Anatomy Resource Centre)

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity through self-directed learning.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Field Work: Time spent in the field. A series of experiments will be carried out each day, ranging from identification experiments, behavioural observations, systematically sampling natural populations, observing how traits allow species to compete or coexist, and investigating ecosystem interactions.

Teaching Method 5

Self-directed video-based learning to introduce applied computational biology skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, bioinformatics tools and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 6

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Computer Practical's are delivered online or synchronously by lecturers and studentâs questions are addressed by lecturers and demonstrators.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the life sciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The lab skills assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills, continual learning and development and appreciation of the theoretical knowledge. Online computational assessment will allow students to implement theoretical knowledge of bioinformatic and computational skills that supplement experimental practices, in order to tackle scientific problems related to wider fields of Biosciences. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific report (s) is highly authentic for practical application of research and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a âsafe spaceâ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and bioinformatics practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.


The mode of assessments include:

1. Online Assessment MCQ/MAQ/EMI Assessment (weighting 30% at the end of teaching block. The questions will require interpretation of lab based experimental techniques and bioinformatics analysis outputs, alongside application of these skills. The students will need to interpret the outputs and understand their significance. (Research connected teaching, Digital Fluency - Liverpool Curriculum). Open book and resit allowed.

2. Practical skills assessment (weighting 20%) based on skills acquired in field specific strand. Can be undertaken via online assessment or physical demonstration (in the case of Whole organism field strand) to assess competency. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

3. Written Scientific Report (s) (weighting 50%) based on the skills to evaluate and interpret and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed


Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

A series of experiments will be carried out each day, ranging from identification experiments, behavioural observations, systematically sampling natural populations, observing how traits allow species to compete or coexist, and investigating ecosystem interactions.

Self-directed video-based learning to introduce applied computational biology skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, bioinformatics tools and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 6

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Computer Practical's are delivered online or synchronously by lecturers and studentâs questions are addressed by lecturers and demonstrators.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the life sciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The lab skills assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills, continual learning and development and appreciation of the theoretical knowledge. Online computational assessment will allow students to implement theoretical knowledge of bioinformatic and computational skills that supplement experimental practices, in order to tackle scientific problems related to wider fields of Biosciences. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific report (s) is highly authentic for practical application of research and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a âsafe spaceâ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and bioinformatics practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.


The mode of assessments include:

1. Online Assessment MCQ/MAQ/EMI Assessment (weighting 30% at the end of teaching block. The questions will require interpretation of lab based experimental techniques and bioinformatics analysis outputs, alongside application of these skills. The students will need to interpret the outputs and understand their significance. (Research connected teaching, Digital Fluency - Liverpool Curriculum). Open book and resit allowed.

2. Practical skills assessment (weighting 20%) based on skills acquired in field specific strand. Can be undertaken via online assessment or physical demonstration (in the case of Whole organism field strand) to assess competency. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

3. Written Scientific Report (s) (weighting 50%) based on the skills to evaluate and interpret and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed


Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to build on initial experience in experimental and computational techniques delivered in the first semester to develop essential practical skills currently used across the Biosciences. The module is designed so that students will acquire fundamental experimental and computational biology techniques that are vital for all aspects of Biosciences, before applying them to field specific problems in one of three topical strands (Molecular Research, Anatomical & Physiological Research, Whole Organism Field Research).

Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advancements in the biosciences, and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative of the student cohort.

This practical will be assessed via three methods: a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of bioinformatic and computational skills; an individual practical skills assessment in the form of observation or online assessment to assess knowledge, understanding and application of knowledge; a written scientific report to assess data analyses and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Educational Aims
1. To provide students with experience in a number of practical techniques, analytical methods and associated computational skills that are applicable to many fields across the Biosciences disciplines.

2. To develop and further understanding of theoretical knowledge in the context of practical skills and exercises.

3. To apply practical & field skills to specific Biosciences disciplines related to topical areas.

4. To train students how to observe and record experiments, and how to present and analyse data

5. To expose students to bioinformatic tools and online databases used in the biosciences and provide students with a practical appreciation of the nature and significance of computational approaches to tackling biological problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Biology is a practical science, whether you want to study disease in microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans), understand the function of a gene, or how the behaviour of organisms can shape an ecosystem. In the first half of this module, all students will learn fundamental practical techniques that every biologist should be familiar with. Alongside the experimental skills, students will learn practical computational and bioinformatic methods that can be used to support and advance scientific understanding of the lab techniques. In the second half, students will split into three topical strands: Molecular Research, Anatomical & Physiological Research or Whole Organism Field Research. Students in each strand will learn a set of skills and techniques that are particularly useful for degree course, with a focus on their specific discipline. All students will learn how to safely and effectively carry out practical biology, skills that will be vital throughout the rest of your degree.

Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advancements in the biosciences, and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative of the student cohort.

This practical will be assessed via three methods: a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of bioinformatic and computational skills; an individual practical skills assessment in the form of observation or online assessment to assess knowledge, understanding and application of knowledge; a written scientific report to assess data analyses and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Outline Syllabus
In the first half of the module, all students will learn fundamental practical techniques that every biologist should be familiar with. In the first part of the module each practical session will be supported by a theoretical bioinformatics session and computational workshop as follows:

Practicals will include:
Topic 1: Molecular tools & DNA. Covering topics such as the extraction of DNA, quantification and quality control methods, including health and safety and methods of good lab practice.

Topic 2: Polymerase Chain Reaction & DNA Mutations. Covering topics such as the amplification of DNA to identify gene mutations related to disease systems.

Topic 3: Use of model systems in Biosciences. Covering topics such as fly cross or plant cross models to showcase functional expression and phenotypic changes

Topic 4: Gene editing. Covering topics such as novel gene editing technologies (e.g. Crispr-CAS) and Genetic Modification (e.g. GMOs and organisms).

Bioinformatics will include:
- Nucleic acid and amino acid sequence alignment methods and tools.
- Primer design.
- Model organism databases.
- Methods for predicting structure, function and interactions of proteins.
- Computational methods to understand phylogeny and evolution.

In the second half of the module students will split into three topical strands: Molecular Biology, Anatomy & Physiology or Whole Organism/Field Biology.

Strand 1: Molecular Biology
Topic A: Plasmid Cloning: May include techniques such as: Restriction digestion of Plasmids; transformation
Topic B: Separation methods for biomolecules. May include techniques such as: gel filtration; ion exchange chromatography
Topic C: Protein purification. May include techniques such as column chromatography
Topic D: SDS-PAGE analyses, protein concentration quantification
Topic E: Protein denaturation and stability analyses

Strand 2: Anatomy & Physiology
Topic A: Plasmid Cloning: May include techniques such as: Restriction digestion of Plasmids; transformation
Topic B: Separation methods for biomolecules. May include techniques such as: gel filtration; ion exchange chromatography
Topic C: Musculoskeletal anatomy and physiological methods
Topic D: Cardiovascular anatomy and physiological methods
Topic E: Respiratory anatomy and physiological methods

Strand 3: Whole Organism/Field Biology
Topic A: Key features of major animals groups
Topic B: Studying populations and their behaviour in the field: assessing behaviour responses and estimating population size
Topic C: Studying species interactions in the field: determining traits of species and how these differences determine interspecies interactions.
Topic D: Studying ecosystem-organism interactions in the field: measuring key ecosystem traits and how they affect and are affected by the species in the ecosystem.
Topic E. Fieldwork safety and experimental design
Teaching and Learning Methods
In a typical week students will attend one or two 1hr lecture/theoretical sessions (one based on the practical work one introducing bioinformatics concepts, a 3 hr practical and a 2hr computational workshop or data analysis session. Students on the whole organism strand weeks 7-12 will also attend fieldwork.

Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also incorporate application of computational biology approaches & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Practical Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills in laboratory (or Human Anatomy Resource Centre)

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity through self-directed learning.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Field Work: Time spent in the field. A series of experiments will be carried out each day, ranging from identification experiments, behavioural observations, systematically sampling natural populations, observing how traits allow species to compete or coexist, and investigating ecosystem interactions.

Teaching Method 5

Self-directed video-based learning to introduce applied computational biology skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, bioinformatics tools and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 6

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Computer Practical's are delivered online or synchronously by lecturers and studentâs questions are addressed by lecturers and demonstrators.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

1. To provide students with experience in a number of practical techniques, analytical methods and associated computational skills that are applicable to many fields across the Biosciences disciplines.

2. To develop and further understanding of theoretical knowledge in the context of practical skills and exercises.

3. To apply practical & field skills to specific Biosciences disciplines related to topical areas.

4. To train students how to observe and record experiments, and how to present and analyse data

5. To expose students to bioinformatic tools and online databases used in the biosciences and provide students with a practical appreciation of the nature and significance of computational approaches to tackling biological problems.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Biology is a practical science, whether you want to study disease in microbes, plants, invertebrate and vertebrate animals (including humans), understand the function of a gene, or how the behaviour of organisms can shape an ecosystem. In the first half of this module, all students will learn fundamental practical techniques that every biologist should be familiar with. Alongside the experimental skills, students will learn practical computational and bioinformatic methods that can be used to support and advance scientific understanding of the lab techniques. In the second half, students will split into three topical strands: Molecular Research, Anatomical & Physiological Research or Whole Organism Field Research. Students in each strand will learn a set of skills and techniques that are particularly useful for degree course, with a focus on their specific discipline. All students will learn how to safely and effectively carry out practical biology, skills that will be vital throughout the rest of your degree.

Learning and teaching is created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advancements in the biosciences, and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative of the student cohort.

This practical will be assessed via three methods: a computer-based assessment to assess understanding of bioinformatic and computational skills; an individual practical skills assessment in the form of observation or online assessment to assess knowledge, understanding and application of knowledge; a written scientific report to assess data analyses and communication of research outputs through scientific writing.
Outline Syllabus
In the first half of the module, all students will learn fundamental practical techniques that every biologist should be familiar with. In the first part of the module each practical session will be supported by a theoretical bioinformatics session and computational workshop as follows:

Practicals will include:
Topic 1: Molecular tools & DNA. Covering topics such as the extraction of DNA, quantification and quality control methods, including health and safety and methods of good lab practice.

Topic 2: Polymerase Chain Reaction & DNA Mutations. Covering topics such as the amplification of DNA to identify gene mutations related to disease systems.

Topic 3: Use of model systems in Biosciences. Covering topics such as fly cross or plant cross models to showcase functional expression and phenotypic changes

Topic 4: Gene editing. Covering topics such as novel gene editing technologies (e.g. Crispr-CAS) and Genetic Modification (e.g. GMOs and organisms).

Bioinformatics will include:
- Nucleic acid and amino acid sequence alignment methods and tools.
- Primer design.
- Model organism databases.
- Methods for predicting structure, function and interactions of proteins.
- Computational methods to understand phylogeny and evolution.

In the second half of the module students will split into three topical strands: Molecular Biology, Anatomy & Physiology or Whole Organism/Field Biology.

Strand 1: Molecular Biology
Topic A: Plasmid Cloning: May include techniques such as: Restriction digestion of Plasmids; transformation
Topic B: Separation methods for biomolecules. May include techniques such as: gel filtration; ion exchange chromatography
Topic C: Protein purification. May include techniques such as column chromatography
Topic D: SDS-PAGE analyses, protein concentration quantification
Topic E: Protein denaturation and stability analyses

Strand 2: Anatomy & Physiology
Topic A: Plasmid Cloning: May include techniques such as: Restriction digestion of Plasmids; transformation
Topic B: Separation methods for biomolecules. May include techniques such as: gel filtration; ion exchange chromatography
Topic C: Musculoskeletal anatomy and physiological methods
Topic D: Cardiovascular anatomy and physiological methods
Topic E: Respiratory anatomy and physiological methods

Strand 3: Whole Organism/Field Biology
Topic A: Key features of major animals groups
Topic B: Studying populations and their behaviour in the field: assessing behaviour responses and estimating population size
Topic C: Studying species interactions in the field: determining traits of species and how these differences determine interspecies interactions.
Topic D: Studying ecosystem-organism interactions in the field: measuring key ecosystem traits and how they affect and are affected by the species in the ecosystem.
Topic E. Fieldwork safety and experimental design
Teaching and Learning Methods
In a typical week students will attend one or two 1hr lecture/theoretical sessions (one based on the practical work one introducing bioinformatics concepts, a 3 hr practical and a 2hr computational workshop or data analysis session. Students on the whole organism strand weeks 7-12 will also attend fieldwork.

Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills. Also incorporate application of computational biology approaches & wider transferable skills to practical problem solving.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Practical Laboratory Work: F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills in laboratory (or Human Anatomy Resource Centre)

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity through self-directed learning.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Field Work: Time spent in the field. A series of experiments will be carried out each day, ranging from identification experiments, behavioural observations, systematically sampling natural populations, observing how traits allow species to compete or coexist, and investigating ecosystem interactions.

Teaching Method 5

Self-directed video-based learning to introduce applied computational biology skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, bioinformatics tools and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 6

Workshop Sessions: Academic led sessions that support problem-based learning approach on implementing data interpretation and visualisation skills. During the workshops, students may engage in smaller groups discussions and research activities on a specific topic related to the module content. Computer Practical's are delivered online or synchronously by lecturers and studentâs questions are addressed by lecturers and demonstrators.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes which are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the breadth of fields of life sciences to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with evidence-based publications of recent clinical, biotechnological and scientific research and application-based conceptualisation, where wider application of practical skills will be demonstrated.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience in order to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain understanding of practical techniques before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques within the life sciences are paramount to active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. Continual feedback provided to students by staff, demonstrators and peers alike allow students to assess the extent of their learning and continually develop. Collaborative discussion and interpretation of practical methods and their application to wider science fosters deeper learning. Furthermore, group working in diverse teams of students from across the department allow students to gain insights in to broader perspectives and communicate findings from a multidisciplinary perspective.

Authentic assessment: There are three assessment components. The lab skills assessment requires students showcase their aptitude for practical skills, continual learning and development and appreciation of the theoretical knowledge. Online computational assessment will allow students to implement theoretical knowledge of bioinformatic and computational skills that supplement experimental practices, in order to tackle scientific problems related to wider fields of Biosciences. The use of student derived data to problem solve will be representative of real-world analytical techniques required in most career pathways. The Written scientific report (s) is highly authentic for practical application of research and offers a comprehensive assessment of specialist knowledge and understanding of practical skills, whilst promoting presentation in a concise manner.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative groupwork and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a âsafe spaceâ for sharing of ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills and provides students with an awareness of good lab practice, risk assessment and safety when working in a practical environment.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners have access to advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools that will assist in the undertaking of data analyses. These are used as part of both lab based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and bioinformatics practices that learners can explore in their own time. Assessment activity also required students to develop competency with digital technology in order to effectively analyse data, communicate findings and present ideas/concepts.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab and field environment, whilst focusing on wider international collaboration in order to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for human impact of their actions, with focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessment components.
Variety of modes of assessment are employed keeping in view inclusivity and diversity.


The mode of assessments include:

1. Online Assessment MCQ/MAQ/EMI Assessment (weighting 30% at the end of teaching block. The questions will require interpretation of lab based experimental techniques and bioinformatics analysis outputs, alongside application of these skills. The students will need to interpret the outputs and understand their significance. (Research connected teaching, Digital Fluency - Liverpool Curriculum). Open book and resit allowed.

2. Practical skills assessment (weighting 20%) based on skills acquired in field specific strand. Can be undertaken via online assessment or physical demonstration (in the case of Whole organism field strand) to assess competency. (Authentic assessment- Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

3. Written Scientific Report (s) (weighting 50%) based on the skills to evaluate and interpret and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed


Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available and will have similar format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 40% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. Details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
